column2: A unique chance to participate in an intensive physical workshop run by the Petra&rsquo
column3: s Pulse Company ~ who make original theatre using a physical vocabulary drawn from dance , Butoh and clowning . They work with simple objects and with their own exposed bodies, objectified in performance, to create space for an audience to find themselves anew.

column1: Thursday 10 th &
Thursday: Book I ~ Friday: Book II
David Burns believes that Paradise Lost was written to be performed on the stage, by Milton, in the first person, and as such he has begun to adapt the epic for the theatre.

column2: ..Burns seeks to 'bring out the music' of Milton's matchless words and succeeds in doing so - The awesome scale of the masterpiece and the magnificent richness of it's language are evoked in almost orchestral manner.&quot

column1: The event is free and begins at 7:30pm on each night: to reserve seats please email Sam Mills (sgm37@cam.ac.uk). Wine will be served after each performance and Clare Hall will host a drinks reception with David on the second night.
For 3 NIGHTS ONLY during May Week:
The Studio Company present:

William Shakespeare: his true chronicle and history of the life and death of King Lear and his three daughters. With the unfortunate life of Edgar, son and heir to the Earl of Gloucester, and his sullen and assumed humour of Tom of Bedlam. 1 The History of King Lear 16 0 3 ~~~~~~ The Tragedy of King Lear 1623
DR E.P. GRIFFITHS AND MR J. G HARDINGHAM . Troilus and Cressida (4 workshops, Tu. 4.30-6.00, Judith E. Wilson Drama Studio, beginning 1 st May)
Each session will focus on one or two scenes from the play. We&rsquo

column6: what the people who are not speaking at any particular moment might be doing. The first workshop will deal with the Prologue. For the second and later meetings, we will be asking for volunteers to participate in various stagings of the selected scenes. But these are not workshops for actors and leotards are not required.

column1: MISCHA TWITCHIN ( Goldsmiths College): Literary Management -the Hollow Men of English Theatre (1S, 2hrs) Wednesday 16 th May 5.30 &ndash

Exploring the seemingly missed encounter with abstraction amongst the managers of 'new writing' in English theatre, this paper will unpick what might be called their 'three-dimensional prejudice'. With consideration of the work of Martin Crimp, the paper will reflect on Michael Fried's 'untimely' contention that "
column2: the success, or even the survival, of the arts has come increasingly to depend on their ability to defeat theatre.&quot
